importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Former Rep. George Santos surrendered to serve 87 months in prison on this date, marking the beginning of his federal sentence.
President Donald Trump commuted Santos' sentence on this date, leading to his immediate release from prison.
George Santos was expelled from Congress on this date, becoming only the sixth lawmaker ever to be expelled from the U.S. House.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Santos committed fraud during his 2022 campaign, leading to his conviction and expulsion from Congress in 2023.

keyTakeAways: Former Rep. George Santos was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence.
Santos pleaded guilty in 2024 to aggravated identity theft and wire fraud related to falsified campaign information.
Santos admitted to fabricating parts of his biography, including employment and education history, leading to his expulsion from Congress in December 2023.
Santos became only the sixth U.S. House member to be expelled from Congress.
Trump commuted the sentence citing concerns over Santos’ prolonged solitary confinement and mistreatment, stating he was 'unfairly treated' and 'put in solitary confinement, which is torture'.
Santos wrote an open letter pleading for 'fairness' and a chance to rebuild, taking full responsibility for his actions.

The commutation drew mixed reactions: supporters like Marjorie Taylor Greene and the law firm representing Santos praised it; House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries criticized Trump for focusing on Santos while ignoring the healthcare crisis.
Santos' case raised public questions about political accountability, campaign integrity, and the use of presidential clemency.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former U.S. Representative George Santos, who was expelled from Congress in December 2023 after pleading guilty to fraud charges related to falsified campaign information, was released from prison on October 18, 2025, following a commutation of his seven-year sentence by President Donald Trump. Santos, who admitted to fabricating parts of his biography, had been serving his sentence at the Federal Correctional Institution in Fairton, New Jersey, and was reportedly subjected to prolonged solitary confinement. Trump cited mistreatment and a lack of fairness in the system as reasons for the commutation, with Santos himself writing an open letter pleading for a chance to rebuild. The move drew support from Republican lawmakers like Marjorie Taylor Greene and others, but faced criticism from House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, who accused Trump of diverting attention from pressing national issues like the healthcare crisis. The incident underscores broader debates about political accountability, campaign ethics, and the use of executive clemency in the U.S. political system.
title: Former Rep. George Santos Released from Prison After Trump Commutes His Sentence
